Marcus Brennan wiped the sweat from his forehead with the back of his wrist, careful not to contaminate his hands as he plated the final dish of the evening rush. The kitchen of Rosemary's Bistro hummed with its usual Friday night chaos, but tonight felt different somehow. Electric. As if the universe itself was holding its breath, waiting for something extraordinary to happen.

The small restaurant tucked away on Third Street in downtown Cheney wasn't much to look at from the outside, but Marcus had poured his heart into every corner of its modest kitchen over the past three years. Since the divorce. Since everything fell apart and he'd fled Seattle with nothing but his knife roll and a determination to start over in this sleepy college town where nobody knew his name or his failures.

"Order up!" Marcus called out, sliding two plates across the pass. The young waitress, Jenny, grabbed them with practiced efficiency and disappeared into the dining room. The ticket rail was finally empty, and Marcus allowed himself a moment to breathe. His sous chef, Tommy, was already breaking down his station, eager to get home to his girlfriend and whatever Netflix series they were binge-watching this week.

"Great service tonight, chef," Tommy said, scraping his cutting board clean. "That new lamb dish is killing it. Table seven asked for the recipe."

Marcus smiled, feeling a familiar warmth spread through his chest. Cooking had always been his first language, the way he made sense of the world when everything else felt chaotic and uncertain. Even during the worst days of his marriage to David, when they could barely look at each other without fighting, he could still find peace in the rhythm of knife work and the alchemy of heat and seasoning.

"Tell them it's a family secret," Marcus replied, though the truth was he'd invented the dish just last week after finding some beautiful spring lamb at the farmer's market. There wasn't much family left to share secrets with anyway. His parents had died in a car accident when he was twenty-five, and his sister lived in Portland now with her own family, their relationship cordial but distant since the divorce.

The kitchen was nearly clean when Marcus's phone buzzed against his hip. He almost ignored it—probably just another vendor trying to sell him overpriced seafood or organic vegetables he couldn't afford. But something made him pause, wipe his hands on his apron, and check the screen.

The text message was from an unknown number, but the words made his heart skip: "Congratulations! You've been selected as a finalist for America's Greatest Dance Challenge. Filming begins Monday in Los Angeles. Please confirm your participation immediately."

Marcus read the message three times before it began to sink in. Dancing? There had to be some mistake. He hadn't danced since... well, since David dragged him to those horrible ballroom lessons five years ago, back when they were still trying to save their marriage through shared hobbies and couple's therapy. Marcus had been terrible at it, stumbling over his own feet while David glided across the floor like he'd been born to waltz.

But even as logic told him this was obviously spam or some kind of scam, another part of his mind was already racing. He remembered sending in that video application months ago during a particularly lonely night when he'd had too much wine and was feeling nostalgic about the early days with David. They used to dance in their tiny apartment kitchen, slow and clumsy to whatever song was playing on the radio while dinner cooked. It had been Marcus's idea to apply for the show—a drunken whim he'd completely forgotten about until now.

His phone rang, startling him out of his thoughts. The caller ID showed a Los Angeles area code.

"Hello?" Marcus answered, his voice uncertain.

"Marcus Brennan? This is Sarah Chen from America's Greatest Dance Challenge. I hope you got our text message. I'm calling to personally congratulate you on making it to our final round. We were absolutely blown away by your audition video."

Marcus leaned against the stainless steel prep counter, feeling dizzy. "I... there must be some mistake. I'm not really a dancer. I mean, I sent that video as kind of a joke..."

"Oh, don't be modest!" Sarah's voice was bright and enthusiastic. "Your contemporary piece to 'Fix You' by Coldplay was incredibly moving. The way you conveyed raw emotion through movement—it gave me chills. Our judges are very excited to work with you."

Contemporary piece? Marcus tried to remember what exactly he'd recorded that night, but the details were fuzzy. He had a vague memory of pushing furniture around in his small apartment, maybe stumbling through some kind of interpretive dance routine while the wine made everything feel profound and meaningful.

"The thing is," Marcus said slowly, "I'm not sure I can just drop everything and fly to Los Angeles. I have a restaurant to run, employees who depend on me..."

"I understand your concerns, but this is the opportunity of a lifetime. The winner receives fifty thousand dollars and a chance to tour with the national company of 'Chicago.' Plus, think of the exposure this could bring to your restaurant. We'd love to feature your culinary background as part of your contestant story."

Fifty thousand dollars. Marcus closed his eyes and thought about the stack of unpaid invoices in his office, the ancient walk-in cooler that needed replacing, the loan payments that kept him awake at night. Rosemary's was barely breaking even, and winter was always slow in a college town when half the population went home for the holidays.

"I need some time to think about it," he said finally.

"Of course, but I do need an answer by tomorrow morning. Filming starts Monday, and we have arrangements to make. Oh, and Marcus? You should know that we're featuring several couples this season, including some former spouses. It creates such compelling television when there's history between the dancers."

The line went quiet, and Marcus felt something cold settle in his stomach. "Former spouses?"

"Yes, it's quite exciting actually. Your ex-husband David submitted his own audition video, and he's also made it to the finals. I hope that won't be a problem? We find that personal drama really helps drive viewership."

Marcus gripped the phone tighter. David? His David—well, his ex-David—was going to be on the show too? The man who'd walked out of their marriage claiming Marcus was too afraid to take risks, too content with his small life and smaller dreams?

"No," Marcus heard himself saying. "No problem at all. I'll be there."

After hanging up, Marcus stood alone in his empty kitchen, surrounded by the familiar smells of garlic and rosemary, and wondered what the hell he'd just agreed to. Through the pass-through window, he could see Jenny wiping down tables in the dining room, and beyond that, the quiet streets of Cheney stretching out under the streetlights. This had been his world for three years—safe, predictable, manageable.

Now he was about to trade it all for a chance to dance on national television alongside the man who'd broken his heart. The man who'd accused him of being afraid to dream big, afraid to fail spectacularly.

Well, Marcus thought as he untied his apron, maybe it was time to prove David wrong about that too.**Chapter 1: The First Step**

Marcus stood in the arrivals terminal at LAX, clutching his small duffel bag and wondering if he'd made the biggest mistake of his life. The California sun streamed through the massive windows, casting everything in a golden hue that seemed almost artificial after the gray Pacific Northwest winter he'd left behind. Travelers rushed past him in all directions, their voices creating a constant buzz of excitement and urgency that made his chest feel tight. He'd barely slept on the red-eye flight from Spokane, spending most of the journey staring out the window and questioning every decision that had led him to this moment.

The past three days had been a whirlwind of arrangements. Tommy had agreed to manage the restaurant while Marcus was away, though his young sous chef's eyes had been wide with panic at the prospect of running Rosemary's single-handedly. Marcus had spent hours writing detailed notes about every aspect of the kitchen operations, from the suppliers' delivery schedules to the precise timing needed for the lamb dish that had become their signature. Jenny and the other servers had promised to help Tommy navigate the front-of-house challenges, but Marcus couldn't shake the feeling that he was abandoning his responsibility to chase some ridiculous fantasy.

A young production assistant with a clipboard and an overly bright smile approached him, her heels clicking against the polished floor. She wore a headset and moved with the kind of efficient energy that Marcus had learned to associate with people who worked in entertainment, all purposeful motion and barely contained enthusiasm. Behind her, Marcus could see other people who looked equally lost and overwhelmed—his fellow contestants, he assumed, each clutching their own bags and wearing expressions that ranged from excitement to terror.

"Marcus Brennan? Welcome to Los Angeles! I'm Ashley, and I'll be your handler for the next few days. We're so excited to have you on the show!" She spoke quickly, already walking toward the exit while Marcus scrambled to keep up. "Your hotel is about twenty minutes away, and we've got wardrobe fittings scheduled for this afternoon, followed by interviews with the producers. Tomorrow we start rehearsals, so I hope you've been stretching!"

Marcus nearly stumbled at the mention of stretching. The closest he'd come to physical preparation was doing some basic yoga videos in his apartment, which had mainly served to remind him how inflexible he'd become after years of standing over stoves and prep tables. His body was strong from the physical demands of kitchen work, but dancing required a completely different kind of strength and grace. He thought about David, who had always been naturally athletic, moving through the world with an easy confidence that Marcus had envied and admired in equal measure.

The ride to the hotel passed in a blur of palm trees and traffic, Ashley chattering constantly about the show's format while Marcus tried to process the information. There would be twelve contestants total, performing both solo pieces and partnerships that would change each week. The judges included a former Broadway star, a professional ballroom champion, and a contemporary choreographer whose name Ashley mentioned with the kind of reverence usually reserved for religious figures. Each week, contestants would be eliminated based on their performances and audience votes, with the finale scheduled to air live in six weeks.

"Now, I have to ask," Ashley said as they pulled up to a sleek modern hotel in West Hollywood, "how do you feel about potentially being partnered with David? Our producers are really interested in exploring that dynamic, especially since you haven't seen each other since the divorce proceedings."

Marcus's stomach clenched at the casual way she mentioned what had been the most painful period of his life. Two years had passed since he and David had signed the papers, sitting in their lawyer's office while rain drummed against the windows and neither of them could quite meet the other's eyes. They'd been together for eight years, married for five, and by the end they'd been like strangers sharing the same space, moving around each other carefully to avoid the sharp edges of their accumulated resentments and disappointments.

"I'm sure it will be fine," Marcus said, though his voice sounded unconvincing even to himself. "We're both professionals. We can handle working together if that's what the show requires."

Ashley's smile suggested she didn't quite believe him, but she made a note on her clipboard anyway. The hotel lobby was all clean lines and modern art, filled with beautiful people who looked like they belonged in this sun-soaked world of dreams and ambition. Marcus felt suddenly conscious of his practical jeans and wrinkled button-down shirt, the uniform of someone who worked with his hands rather than performed under bright lights. The other guests moved through the space with an easy confidence that reminded him uncomfortably of David, who had always seemed to belong wherever he went.

His room was on the fifteenth floor, with a view of the Hollywood Hills that would have taken his breath away under different circumstances. Instead, Marcus found himself staring at his reflection in the floor-to-ceiling windows, trying to reconcile the man looking back at him with the person who had somehow convinced a television production company that he could dance. His brown hair was longer than it had been during his marriage, touching his collar in a way that David had always said made him look unprofessional. His face showed the lines that came from three years of running a restaurant, the stress and long hours etched around his eyes and mouth.

The phone rang, startling him out of his self-examination. For a wild moment, he thought it might be David, that somehow his ex-husband had gotten his room number and was calling to... what? Apologize for the past? Warn him about the challenges ahead? Suggest they work together to navigate this bizarre situation they'd both stumbled into?

Instead, it was Sarah Chen, the producer who had called him in his kitchen just four days earlier, though it felt like a lifetime ago. Her voice was warm but businesslike, and Marcus could hear the sounds of a busy production office in the background—phones ringing, people talking, the constant motion of a television show coming together.

"Marcus, I hope you're settling in well. I wanted to touch base before the craziness really begins tomorrow. I know this must feel overwhelming, especially with David being here too, but I want you to know that we're committed to handling your situation with sensitivity and respect." She paused, and Marcus could almost see her consulting her notes. "That said, our audience research shows tremendous interest in the personal dynamics between contestants, particularly when there's romantic history involved. I hope you'll be open to sharing some of that journey with our viewers."Marcus set the phone down and walked to the window, pressing his palm against the cool glass. The Hollywood Hills stretched out before him, dotted with houses that probably cost more than his restaurant would make in a decade. Below, traffic moved in steady streams along Sunset Boulevard, and he could see people walking along the sidewalks with the kind of purposeful stride that suggested they all had somewhere important to be, dreams to chase, meetings that might change their lives forever.

He thought about Sarah's words regarding sharing his journey with viewers, and a familiar knot of anxiety formed in his chest. The divorce had been difficult enough to navigate privately, with only their closest friends and family knowing the details of how their marriage had slowly unraveled. The idea of exposing those wounds on national television, of having strangers analyze and judge the most painful period of his life, made him feel sick. But then he remembered the stack of bills waiting for him back in Cheney, the worried expression on Tommy's face when Marcus had explained that the restaurant's survival might depend on the exposure this show could provide.

The irony wasn't lost on him that he was here because of David, in more ways than one. It had been David's criticism—that Marcus was too safe, too unwilling to take risks—that had led to their final fight. David had accused him of being content with mediocrity, of choosing the comfortable path instead of pursuing the culinary dreams he'd once talked about with such passion. At the time, Marcus had been furious, but in the quiet months that followed, he'd begun to wonder if his ex-husband had been right. Opening Rosemary's had been a risk, certainly, but it had also been a retreat, a way of creating a small, manageable world where he couldn't be hurt or disappointed on the same scale.

Now here he was, about to perform on national television alongside professional dancers, having committed to something so far outside his comfort zone that it felt like stepping off a cliff. If that wasn't taking a risk, he didn't know what was. Part of him wondered if this was less about the money or the restaurant and more about proving something to David, about showing the man who had once known him better than anyone that he was capable of change, of growth, of the kind of bold choices that had seemed impossible during their marriage.

His phone buzzed with a text message from Tommy: "Day one without the boss and the kitchen hasn't burned down yet. Jenny dropped a whole tray of water glasses but we're handling it. Don't worry about us and break a leg out there. Metaphorically speaking." The message was followed by a string of emojis that made Marcus smile despite his nerves. His staff had been surprisingly supportive of his sudden departure, even excited about the possibility of their restaurant being featured on television. It reminded him that he wasn't just doing this for himself—there were people back home counting on him to succeed.

Another text came through, this one from his sister Claire in Portland: "Saw the news online that you're on the show. Mom and Dad would have been so proud of you for taking a chance like this. Can't wait to vote for you every week. Try not to let David get under your skin too much." Marcus stared at the message for a long time, feeling the familiar ache that came with missing his parents. They had died just two years into his marriage to David, and he'd often wondered how different things might have been if they'd lived to see the relationship struggle and eventually fail. His mother had adored David, had been thrilled when Marcus brought home someone who could match her son's intelligence and ambition.

The afternoon wardrobe fitting took place in a converted warehouse in Burbank, where racks of clothing in every color imaginable lined the walls like a rainbow that had exploded and been carefully organized by size and style. The costume designers, a husband-and-wife team named Roberto and Linda, circled Marcus like friendly predators, taking measurements and making notes while discussing his "look" as if he weren't standing right there in his underwear. They draped various fabrics against his skin, debating whether jewel tones or earth tones would work better with his coloring, whether he should lean into the "rugged chef" aesthetic or try for something more polished and contemporary.

"We want the audience to see your transformation," Linda explained while pinning a burgundy shirt that probably cost more than Marcus spent on groceries in a month. "From small-town restaurant owner to confident performer. The wardrobe needs to tell that story along with your dancing." She stepped back to examine her work, tilting her head thoughtfully. "Roberto, what do you think about adding some subtle sparkle to his performance pieces? Nothing too flashy, but something that catches the light when he moves."

Roberto nodded enthusiastically, already pulling sequined fabric samples from a nearby drawer. "Yes, but we keep it masculine, sophisticated. He's not a Vegas showgirl, he's an artist expressing himself through movement." They continued their discussion as if Marcus were a mannequin, and he found himself wondering how many other people had stood in this same spot, being transformed from ordinary individuals into television personalities.

The interview session that followed was held in a small studio filled with professional lighting equipment and cameras that looked intimidatingly expensive. Marcus sat in a chair that was positioned to catch the afternoon light streaming through carefully positioned windows, while a makeup artist touched up his face and a sound technician clipped a small microphone to his shirt. The producer conducting the interview, a woman named Jennifer with kind eyes and a warm smile, explained that these segments would be used throughout the season to provide context and backstory for the viewers.

"Let's start with something easy," Jennifer said, settling into her chair across from him. "Tell me about your restaurant. What made you decide to leave Seattle and open Rosemary's in Cheney?" Her voice was conversational, but Marcus could see the camera operators adjusting their equipment, and he felt suddenly self-conscious about every word, every gesture, every expression that might be broadcast to millions of people.

He talked about the divorce, though in carefully neutral terms, explaining how he'd wanted a fresh start somewhere nobody knew his story. He described the challenges of running a small restaurant, the satisfaction of creating dishes that brought joy to people's lives, the way cooking had always been his form of artistic expression. Jennifer nodded encouragingly, asking follow-up questions that drew out more details, and gradually Marcus began to relax into the conversation.

"Now, I have to ask about David," Jennifer said gently, and Marcus felt his shoulders tense despite his best efforts to remain calm. "You two were married for five years. What was that relationship like, and how do you feel about potentially working with him again on this show?" The question hung in the air between them, and Marcus could feel the weight of the cameras capturing his reaction, the way his jaw tightened slightly and his hands gripped the arms of his chair.

Marcus took a deep breath, choosing his words carefully. "David and I had a good relationship for a long time. We supported each other's careers, we traveled together, we built a life that worked for both of us. But eventually, we grew in different directions, wanted different things. The divorce was difficult, but it was the right decision for both of us." He paused, looking directly into the camera for the first time. "As for working with him on the show, I think we're both professional enough to focus on the dancing and the competition. Whatever personal history we have, we left that behind two years ago."

Even as he said the words, Marcus wasn't sure he believed them. The truth was more complicated, messier, full of the kind of emotional landmines that made for compelling television but terrible life experiences. David hadn't just been his husband; he'd been his best friend, his confidant, the person he'd imagined growing old with. The end of their marriage had felt like losing half of himself, and he'd spent the past two years learning how to be whole again as a single person. The idea of seeing David again, of potentially having to touch him, dance with him, pretend that they were just two people who happened to share a past, felt both terrifying and oddly thrilling.**Chapter 2: Reunions and Revelations**

The morning sun was barely creeping over the Los Angeles skyline when Marcus arrived at the rehearsal studio, his stomach churning with a mixture of anticipation and dread that had kept him awake most of the night. The building was a converted warehouse in the arts district, its industrial exterior giving way to polished wood floors and floor-to-ceiling mirrors that reflected the early morning light in dizzying patterns. He'd arrived thirty minutes early, hoping to have some time to acclimate to the space before facing the other contestants, but as he pushed through the heavy glass doors, he realized he wasn't the only one who'd had that idea.

David stood at the center of the main studio, moving through what looked like a warm-up routine, his body flowing from one position to another with the kind of natural grace that had always made Marcus feel clumsy by comparison. He was wearing fitted black dance pants and a gray tank top that showed off the lean muscle definition he'd maintained since their college days, when he'd played tennis and run marathons while Marcus had been more interested in exploring the local food scene. His dark hair was shorter than Marcus remembered, cut in a style that emphasized the sharp angles of his jaw and cheekbones, and when he turned to grab his water bottle, Marcus caught sight of the small scar above his left eyebrow that he'd gotten falling off his bike when they were twenty-six and still thought they'd be together forever.

For a moment, Marcus considered backing out of the studio and finding somewhere else to warm up, maybe coming back when there were more people around to serve as a buffer between them. But something in David's posture, the way he was holding his shoulders just a little too high, suggested that he was just as nervous about this reunion as Marcus was. Two years was a long time to go without speaking to someone who had once been the most important person in your life, long enough for all the sharp edges of anger and hurt to wear smooth, leaving behind something more complicated and harder to define.

David must have seen his reflection in the mirror because he turned around, and for a heartbeat they just looked at each other across the empty studio. Marcus felt the familiar jolt of recognition that came from seeing someone whose face had once been as familiar as his own, noting the subtle changes that time and distance had wrought. There were new lines around David's eyes, and he'd lost some of the softness that had been there during their marriage, when stress and late nights had made both of them a little rounder around the edges. He looked good, Marcus realized with an uncomfortable twist in his chest, like someone who had found his footing after a difficult period and was moving forward with purpose and confidence.

"Hello, Marcus," David said, his voice carrying easily across the space between them. It was the same voice that had whispered good morning in Marcus's ear for five years, that had argued with him about everything from dinner plans to major life decisions, that had said "I think we both know this isn't working" on that terrible rainy afternoon that had effectively ended their marriage. Hearing it now, in this strange context, made Marcus feel like he'd stepped backward in time, even as everything else about their situation was completely surreal.

Marcus set his bag down by the wall and walked closer, trying to project a casualness he didn't feel. "David. You look..." He paused, unsure how to finish that sentence in a way that wouldn't reveal too much about the complicated knot of emotions currently residing in his chest. "You look well. I didn't know you were still dancing." It was a safe observation, neutral territory that acknowledged their shared past without venturing into more dangerous conversational waters.

"I started taking classes again after we..." David made a vague gesture that encompassed their divorce, their separation, the entire messy end of their relationship. "It helped with the stress, gave me something physical to focus on. I never imagined it would lead to something like this, though." He gestured around the studio, and Marcus could see the same mix of excitement and terror in his ex-husband's eyes that he'd been feeling since getting on the plane in Spokane.

They stood there for a moment in awkward silence, and Marcus found himself cataloging the familiar details of David's face, the way his left eyebrow had always been slightly higher than his right, the small freckle just below his bottom lip that Marcus had kissed countless times during their years together. It was disorienting to be this close to someone who had once shared his bed, his dreams, his daily routines, and now felt like a stranger wearing a familiar face. The intimacy they'd once shared seemed like something that had happened to different people, a story he'd heard secondhand rather than lived through himself.

"How's the restaurant?" David asked, and Marcus could hear genuine interest in his voice despite everything that had passed between them. During their marriage, David had been supportive of Marcus's culinary ambitions, had encouraged him to take risks and pursue opportunities that Marcus had been too afraid to attempt. It had been one of the sources of tension between them toward the end, David's frustration with what he saw as Marcus's unwillingness to dream bigger, to step outside his comfort zone and really reach for the success he was capable of achieving.

"It's good. Small, but we're building a following. The food scene in Cheney isn't exactly Seattle, but there's something to be said for being the only game in town." Marcus realized he was downplaying his success, falling back into old patterns of self-deprecation that had driven David crazy during their marriage. Rosemary's was actually doing better than just good – they'd been featured in several regional magazines, and food bloggers were starting to make the drive from Spokane specifically to try his menu. But talking about his achievements with David felt dangerous somehow, like claiming too much success might invite criticism or comparison.

David's smile was complicated, mixing what looked like genuine pride with something that might have been regret. "I'm glad you took the leap. I always knew you had it in you to run your own place." The words hung between them, loaded with the history of their arguments about Marcus's career, his tendency to choose security over opportunity, the way he'd turned down jobs in better restaurants because they would have meant longer hours or more pressure or the possibility of failure on a larger stage.

Before Marcus could formulate a response that wouldn't lead them into the minefield of their shared past, the studio doors opened and other contestants began filtering in. Marcus felt a mixture of relief and disappointment as their private moment was interrupted, the space filling with the chatter and energy of people preparing for what they all knew would be a challenging day. He recognized a few faces from the brief glimpses he'd caught at the airport and hotel – there was a young woman with bright red hair who moved like a trained dancer, an older man who looked like he might be a ballroom specialist, and several others whose backgrounds and stories Marcus could only guess at.

The arrival of the other contestants shifted the dynamic in the room, transforming it from an intimate space where two ex-husbands were carefully navigating their first conversation in two years into a professional environment where everyone was sizing up the competition. Marcus found himself grateful for the distraction, using the opportunity to put some physical distance between himself and David while still maintaining the pretense that their reunion was no big deal, just two mature adults who happened to share some history.

Ashley, the production assistant who had picked him up at the airport, appeared with her ever-present clipboard and that bright smile that seemed to be permanently fixed to her face. She was followed by several camera operators and sound technicians, and Marcus realized that their morning warm-up was going to be filmed, their interactions and reactions captured for potential use in future episodes. The presence of the cameras changed everything, adding a layer of performance to even the most mundane interactions, and he saw several contestants unconsciously straightening their posture and arranging their faces into more television-appropriate expressions.

"Good morning, everyone!" Ashley's voice carried easily through the studio, cutting through the various conversations and drawing everyone's attention to where she stood near the mirrors. "Welcome to day one of rehearsals for America's Greatest Dance Challenge. We're going to start this morning with individual assessments, where our choreographers will work with each of you to get a sense of your current skill level and discuss the pieces you'll be performing for tomorrow night's premiere episode." She consulted her clipboard, and Marcus felt his stomach drop as he realized that everything was moving much faster than he'd anticipated.

The choreographers were introduced as Elena Martinez, a former principal dancer with the American Ballet Theatre who would be handling the contemporary and lyrical pieces; Michael Chen, a ballroom champion who had appeared on several other dance reality shows; and Jasmine Williams, whose credits included music videos for major pop stars and choreography for Broadway productions. They were all impossibly elegant and intimidating, moving with the kind of physical confidence that made Marcus acutely aware of his own limitations and inexperience.

"We'll be calling you one at a time for your individual sessions," Ashley continued, "and this afternoon we'll start working on the group number that will open tomorrow's show. Remember, everything you do here is being filmed, so please keep that in mind as you interact with your fellow contestants and our production team." Her smile became even brighter, if that was possible, and Marcus wondered if that warning was directed at him and David specifically, a gentle reminder that their personal drama was part of the entertainment value they were expected to provide.

The waiting was almost worse than the actual dancing would be, Marcus realized as he watched the first contestant, a young man who introduced himself as Tyler and mentioned that he'd been dancing since he was four, disappear into one of the smaller rehearsal rooms with Elena. The rest of them were left to warm up and make small talk, but the presence of the cameras made even casual conversation feel stilted and artificial. Marcus found himself gravitating toward a corner where he could stretch and try to calm his nerves without being in the direct line of sight of any of the camera operators.

He was in the middle of what he hoped looked like a professional warm-up routine when David appeared beside him, close enough that Marcus could smell the familiar scent of his cologne, something woody and expensive that he'd worn for as long as Marcus had known him. "This is surreal," David said quietly, his voice pitched low enough that the microphones probably wouldn't pick it up. "Two days ago I was reviewing quarterly reports, and now I'm about to be critiqued on my pirouettes by someone who danced at Lincoln Center."

Marcus looked up from his attempt at touching his toes, surprised by the vulnerability in David's voice. During their marriage, David had rarely admitted to feeling uncertain about anything, projecting confidence even when Marcus knew he was struggling with doubt or insecurity. "What do you do now?" Marcus asked, realizing that he knew almost nothing about David's life since their divorce, had deliberately avoided any information that might have filtered back through mutual friends or social media.

"I'm a financial consultant, specializing in small business development," David replied, and Marcus could hear a note of pride in his voice. "I help restaurants and retail operations streamline their finances, plan for expansion, that sort of thing." He paused, and Marcus could feel him looking in his direction. "Actually, I've been wondering if maybe I could take a look at Rosemary's books sometime, see if there are any opportunities for optimization. No charge, obviously. Just... I'd like to help if I can."

The offer caught Marcus completely off guard, hitting him somewhere in the region of his solar plexus with its casual generosity and implicit suggestion that David had been thinking about him, about his restaurant, about whether he was succeeding or struggling in his new life. During their marriage, David had often tried to give Marcus business advice, suggestions about marketing and financial planning that Marcus had sometimes interpreted as criticism of his methods. Now, two years later, the same offer felt different somehow, less like judgment and more like genuine concern.

"I... that's generous of you," Marcus managed, unsure how to respond to this unexpected olive branch. "Things are actually going pretty well, but I could probably use some help with the bookkeeping side of things. I'm still more of a cook than a businessman." It was an admission that would have been difficult to make during their marriage, when Marcus had been defensive about any suggestion that he wasn't handling every aspect of his career with complete competence.

Before David could respond, Ashley called Marcus's name, and he felt his heart rate spike as he realized it was his turn to face the choreographers' assessment. He grabbed his water bottle and headed toward the rehearsal room where Elena was waiting, but not before catching David's eye in the mirror and seeing something there that looked almost like encouragement, a silent message that maybe, despite everything that had happened between them, David was still rooting for him to succeed.

The individual assessment was simultaneously better and worse than Marcus had feared. Elena was patient and encouraging, walking him through some basic contemporary movement sequences and asking him to show her what he remembered from his original audition video. The problem was that Marcus barely remembered recording that video, let alone the specific movements he'd apparently performed while under the influence of wine and nostalgia. He found himself stumbling through what he hoped were artistic interpretations of the emotions he'd been feeling that night, trying to translate feelings of loss and hope and determination into physical movement that made sense to someone watching.

"You have good instincts," Elena said after watching him attempt what she generously called a "contemporary expression piece." "Your movement comes from a genuine place, which is more important than technical perfection at this stage. We can work on the technique, but authenticity is something you either have or you don't." She made notes on a tablet while talking, and Marcus wondered what exactly she was writing about his performance, whether his lack of formal training was as obvious as it felt to him.

They spent the next hour working on basic positions and transitions, Elena gently correcting his posture and alignment while explaining how to use his breath to support his movement. It was harder physical work than Marcus had anticipated, engaging muscles he didn't know he had and requiring a kind of coordination between mind and body that felt completely foreign after years of focusing his physical energy on knife work and line cooking. You looked like you were having genuine fun up there, which is something I always hoped you'd discover about yourself but wasn't sure you'd ever feel comfortable enough to access." Marcus found himself able to ask David about his own preparation for the ballroom routine he would be performing later in the show, genuinely curious about his ex-husband's experience learning a completely new style and working with Michael Chen to develop the elegance and precision that ballroom dancing required. Their exchange felt like the kind of supportive professional conversation that might occur between any two artists who respected each other's work and were interested in each other's creative processes, unmarked by the emotional complications that had initially made their interactions so difficult to navigate.

When David's turn came to perform his individual routine, Marcus watched from the wings with genuine investment in his ex-husband's success, understanding now how much courage and preparation each performance required regardless of the contestant's background or previous experience. David's ballroom piece was elegant and technically accomplished, showcasing the analytical approach and methodical preparation that had always characterized his approach to new challenges during their marriage, but also revealing a grace and artistic sensitivity that Marcus had rarely seen him display in other contexts. The performance was compelling not just for its technical competence but for the way it revealed new dimensions of David's personality and capability, demonstrating the same kind of personal growth through artistic exploration that Marcus had been experiencing throughout his own competition journey.

Marcus Brennan wiped the sweat from his forehead with the back of his wrist, careful not to contaminate his hands as he plated the final dish of the evening rush. The kitchen of Rosemary's Bistro hummed with its usual Friday night chaos, but tonight felt different somehow. Electric. As if the universe itself was holding its breath, waiting for something extraordinary to happen.

The small restaurant tucked away on Third Street in downtown Cheney wasn't much to look at from the outside, but Marcus had poured his heart into every corner of its modest kitchen over the past three years. Since the divorce. Since everything fell apart and he'd fled Seattle with nothing but his knife roll and a determination to start over in this sleepy college town where nobody knew his name or his failures.

"Order up!" Marcus called out, sliding two plates across the pass. The young waitress, Jenny, grabbed them with practiced efficiency and disappeared into the dining room. The ticket rail was finally empty, and Marcus allowed himself a moment to breathe. His sous chef, Tommy, was already breaking down his station, eager to get home to his girlfriend and whatever Netflix series they were binge-watching this week.

"Great service tonight, chef," Tommy said, scraping his cutting board clean. "That new lamb dish is killing it. Table seven asked for the recipe."

Marcus smiled, feeling a familiar warmth spread through his chest. Cooking had always been his first language, the way he made sense of the world when everything else felt chaotic and uncertain. Even during the worst days of his marriage to David, when they could barely look at each other without fighting, he could still find peace in the rhythm of knife work and the alchemy of heat and seasoning.

"Tell them it's a family secret," Marcus replied, though the truth was he'd invented the dish just last week after finding some beautiful spring lamb at the farmer's market. There wasn't much family left to share secrets with anyway. His parents had died in a car accident when he was twenty-five, and his sister lived in Portland now with her own family, their relationship cordial but distant since the divorce.

The kitchen was nearly clean when Marcus's phone buzzed against his hip. He almost ignored it—probably just another vendor trying to sell him overpriced seafood or organic vegetables he couldn't afford. But something made him pause, wipe his hands on his apron, and check the screen.

The text message was from an unknown number, but the words made his heart skip: "Congratulations! You've been selected as a finalist for America's Greatest Dance Challenge. Filming begins Monday in Los Angeles. Please confirm your participation immediately."

Marcus read the message three times before it began to sink in. Dancing? There had to be some mistake. He hadn't danced since... well, since David dragged him to those horrible ballroom lessons five years ago, back when they were still trying to save their marriage through shared hobbies and couple's therapy. Marcus had been terrible at it, stumbling over his own feet while David glided across the floor like he'd been born to waltz.

But even as logic told him this was obviously spam or some kind of scam, another part of his mind was already racing. He remembered sending in that video application months ago during a particularly lonely night when he'd had too much wine and was feeling nostalgic about the early days with David. They used to dance in their tiny apartment kitchen, slow and clumsy to whatever song was playing on the radio while dinner cooked. It had been Marcus's idea to apply for the show—a drunken whim he'd completely forgotten about until now.

His phone rang, startling him out of his thoughts. The caller ID showed a Los Angeles area code.

"Hello?" Marcus answered, his voice uncertain.

"Marcus Brennan? This is Sarah Chen from America's Greatest Dance Challenge. I hope you got our text message. I'm calling to personally congratulate you on making it to our final round. We were absolutely blown away by your audition video."

Marcus leaned against the stainless steel prep counter, feeling dizzy. "I... there must be some mistake. I'm not really a dancer. I mean, I sent that video as kind of a joke..."

"Oh, don't be modest!" Sarah's voice was bright and enthusiastic. "Your contemporary piece to 'Fix You' by Coldplay was incredibly moving. The way you conveyed raw emotion through movement—it gave me chills. Our judges are very excited to work with you."

Contemporary piece? Marcus tried to remember what exactly he'd recorded that night, but the details were fuzzy. He had a vague memory of pushing furniture around in his small apartment, maybe stumbling through some kind of interpretive dance routine while the wine made everything feel profound and meaningful.

"The thing is," Marcus said slowly, "I'm not sure I can just drop everything and fly to Los Angeles. I have a restaurant to run, employees who depend on me..."

"I understand your concerns, but this is the opportunity of a lifetime. The winner receives fifty thousand dollars and a chance to tour with the national company of 'Chicago.' Plus, think of the exposure this could bring to your restaurant. We'd love to feature your culinary background as part of your contestant story."

Fifty thousand dollars. Marcus closed his eyes and thought about the stack of unpaid invoices in his office, the ancient walk-in cooler that needed replacing, the loan payments that kept him awake at night. Rosemary's was barely breaking even, and winter was always slow in a college town when half the population went home for the holidays.

"I need some time to think about it," he said finally.

"Of course, but I do need an answer by tomorrow morning. Filming starts Monday, and we have arrangements to make. Oh, and Marcus? You should know that we're featuring several couples this season, including some former spouses. It creates such compelling television when there's history between the dancers."

The line went quiet, and Marcus felt something cold settle in his stomach. "Former spouses?"

"Yes, it's quite exciting actually. Your ex-husband David submitted his own audition video, and he's also made it to the finals. I hope that won't be a problem? We find that personal drama really helps drive viewership."

Marcus gripped the phone tighter. David? His David—well, his ex-David—was going to be on the show too? The man who'd walked out of their marriage claiming Marcus was too afraid to take risks, too content with his small life and smaller dreams?

"No," Marcus heard himself saying. "No problem at all. I'll be there."

After hanging up, Marcus stood alone in his empty kitchen, surrounded by the familiar smells of garlic and rosemary, and wondered what the hell he'd just agreed to. Through the pass-through window, he could see Jenny wiping down tables in the dining room, and beyond that, the quiet streets of Cheney stretching out under the streetlights. This had been his world for three years—safe, predictable, manageable.

Now he was about to trade it all for a chance to dance on national television alongside the man who'd broken his heart. The man who'd accused him of being afraid to dream big, afraid to fail spectacularly.

Well, Marcus thought as he untied his apron, maybe it was time to prove David wrong about that too.

**Chapter 1: The First Step**

Marcus stood in the arrivals terminal at LAX, clutching his small duffel bag and wondering if he'd made the biggest mistake of his life. The California sun streamed through the massive windows, casting everything in a golden hue that seemed almost artificial after the gray Pacific Northwest winter he'd left behind. Travelers rushed past him in all directions, their voices creating a constant buzz of excitement and urgency that made his chest feel tight. He'd barely slept on the red-eye flight from Spokane, spending most of the journey staring out the window and questioning every decision that had led him to this moment.

The past three days had been a whirlwind of arrangements. Tommy had agreed to manage the restaurant while Marcus was away, though his young sous chef's eyes had been wide with panic at the prospect of running Rosemary's single-handedly. Marcus had spent hours writing detailed notes about every aspect of the kitchen operations, from the suppliers' delivery schedules to the precise timing needed for the lamb dish that had become their signature. Jenny and the other servers had promised to help Tommy navigate the front-of-house challenges, but Marcus couldn't shake the feeling that he was abandoning his responsibility to chase some ridiculous fantasy.

A young production assistant with a clipboard and an overly bright smile approached him, her heels clicking against the polished floor. She wore a headset and moved with the kind of efficient energy that Marcus had learned to associate with people who worked in entertainment, all purposeful motion and barely contained enthusiasm. Behind her, Marcus could see other people who looked equally lost and overwhelmed—his fellow contestants, he assumed, each clutching their own bags and wearing expressions that ranged from excitement to terror.

"Marcus Brennan? Welcome to Los Angeles! I'm Ashley, and I'll be your handler for the next few days. We're so excited to have you on the show!" She spoke quickly, already walking toward the exit while Marcus scrambled to keep up. "Your hotel is about twenty minutes away, and we've got wardrobe fittings scheduled for this afternoon, followed by interviews with the producers. Tomorrow we start rehearsals, so I hope you've been stretching!"

Marcus nearly stumbled at the mention of stretching. The closest he'd come to physical preparation was doing some basic yoga videos in his apartment, which had mainly served to remind him how inflexible he'd become after years of standing over stoves and prep tables. His body was strong from the physical demands of kitchen work, but dancing required a completely different kind of strength and grace. He thought about David, who had always been naturally athletic, moving through the world with an easy confidence that Marcus had envied and admired in equal measure.

The ride to the hotel passed in a blur of palm trees and traffic, Ashley chattering constantly about the show's format while Marcus tried to process the information. There would be twelve contestants total, performing both solo pieces and partnerships that would change each week. The judges included a former Broadway star, a professional ballroom champion, and a contemporary choreographer whose name Ashley mentioned with the kind of reverence usually reserved for religious figures. Each week, contestants would be eliminated based on their performances and audience votes, with the finale scheduled to air live in six weeks.

"Now, I have to ask," Ashley said as they pulled up to a sleek modern hotel in West Hollywood, "how do you feel about potentially being partnered with David? Our producers are really interested in exploring that dynamic, especially since you haven't seen each other since the divorce proceedings."

Marcus's stomach clenched at the casual way she mentioned what had been the most painful period of his life. Two years had passed since he and David had signed the papers, sitting in their lawyer's office while rain drummed against the windows and neither of them could quite meet the other's eyes. They'd been together for eight years, married for five, and by the end they'd been like strangers sharing the same space, moving around each other carefully to avoid the sharp edges of their accumulated resentments and disappointments.

"I'm sure it will be fine," Marcus said, though his voice sounded unconvincing even to himself. "We're both professionals. We can handle working together if that's what the show requires."

Ashley's smile suggested she didn't quite believe him, but she made a note on her clipboard anyway. The hotel lobby was all clean lines and modern art, filled with beautiful people who looked like they belonged in this sun-soaked world of dreams and ambition. Marcus felt suddenly conscious of his practical jeans and wrinkled button-down shirt, the uniform of someone who worked with his hands rather than performed under bright lights. The other guests moved through the space with an easy confidence that reminded him uncomfortably of David, who had always seemed to belong wherever he went.

His room was on the fifteenth floor, with a view of the Hollywood Hills that would have taken his breath away under different circumstances. Instead, Marcus found himself staring at his reflection in the floor-to-ceiling windows, trying to reconcile the man looking back at him with the person who had somehow convinced a television production company that he could dance. His brown hair was longer than it had been during his marriage, touching his collar in a way that David had always said made him look unprofessional. His face showed the lines that came from three years of running a restaurant, the stress and long hours etched around his eyes and mouth.

The phone rang, startling him out of his self-examination. For a wild moment, he thought it might be David, that somehow his ex-husband had gotten his room number and was calling to... what? Apologize for the past? Warn him about the challenges ahead? Suggest they work together to navigate this bizarre situation they'd both stumbled into?

Instead, it was Sarah Chen, the producer who had called him in his kitchen just four days earlier, though it felt like a lifetime ago. Her voice was warm but businesslike, and Marcus could hear the sounds of a busy production office in the background—phones ringing, people talking, the constant motion of a television show coming together.

"Marcus, I hope you're settling in well. I wanted to touch base before the craziness really begins tomorrow. I know this must feel overwhelming, especially with David being here too, but I want you to know that we're committed to handling your situation with sensitivity and respect." She paused, and Marcus could almost see her consulting her notes. "That said, our audience research shows tremendous interest in the personal dynamics between contestants, particularly when there's romantic history involved. I hope you'll be open to sharing some of that journey with our viewers."

Marcus set the phone down and walked to the window, pressing his palm against the cool glass. The Hollywood Hills stretched out before him, dotted with houses that probably cost more than his restaurant would make in a decade. Below, traffic moved in steady streams along Sunset Boulevard, and he could see people walking along the sidewalks with the kind of purposeful stride that suggested they all had somewhere important to be, dreams to chase, meetings that might change their lives forever.

He thought about Sarah's words regarding sharing his journey with viewers, and a familiar knot of anxiety formed in his chest. The divorce had been difficult enough to navigate privately, with only their closest friends and family knowing the details of how their marriage had slowly unraveled. The idea of exposing those wounds on national television, of having strangers analyze and judge the most painful period of his life, made him feel sick. But then he remembered the stack of bills waiting for him back in Cheney, the worried expression on Tommy's face when Marcus had explained that the restaurant's survival might depend on the exposure this show could provide.

The irony wasn't lost on him that he was here because of David, in more ways than one. It had been David's criticism—that Marcus was too safe, too unwilling to take risks—that had led to their final fight. David had accused him of being content with mediocrity, of choosing the comfortable path instead of pursuing the culinary dreams he'd once talked about with such passion. At the time, Marcus had been furious, but in the quiet months that followed, he'd begun to wonder if his ex-husband had been right. Opening Rosemary's had been a risk, certainly, but it had also been a retreat, a way of creating a small, manageable world where he couldn't be hurt or disappointed on the same scale.

Now here he was, about to perform on national television alongside professional dancers, having committed to something so far outside his comfort zone that it felt like stepping off a cliff. If that wasn't taking a risk, he didn't know what was. Part of him wondered if this was less about the money or the restaurant and more about proving something to David, about showing the man who had once known him better than anyone that he was capable of change, of growth, of the kind of bold choices that had seemed impossible during their marriage.

His phone buzzed with a text message from Tommy: "Day one without the boss and the kitchen hasn't burned down yet. Jenny dropped a whole tray of water glasses but we're handling it. Don't worry about us and break a leg out there. Metaphorically speaking." The message was followed by a string of emojis that made Marcus smile despite his nerves. His staff had been surprisingly supportive of his sudden departure, even excited about the possibility of their restaurant being featured on television. It reminded him that he wasn't just doing this for himself—there were people back home counting on him to succeed.

Another text came through, this one from his sister Claire in Portland: "Saw the news online that you're on the show. Mom and Dad would have been so proud of you for taking a chance like this. Can't wait to vote for you every week. Try not to let David get under your skin too much." Marcus stared at the message for a long time, feeling the familiar ache that came with missing his parents. They had died just two years into his marriage to David, and he'd often wondered how different things might have been if they'd lived to see the relationship struggle and eventually fail. His mother had adored David, had been thrilled when Marcus brought home someone who could match her son's intelligence and ambition.

The afternoon wardrobe fitting took place in a converted warehouse in Burbank, where racks of clothing in every color imaginable lined the walls like a rainbow that had exploded and been carefully organized by size and style. The costume designers, a husband-and-wife team named Roberto and Linda, circled Marcus like friendly predators, taking measurements and making notes while discussing his "look" as if he weren't standing right there in his underwear. They draped various fabrics against his skin, debating whether jewel tones or earth tones would work better with his coloring, whether he should lean into the "rugged chef" aesthetic or try for something more polished and contemporary.

"We want the audience to see your transformation," Linda explained while pinning a burgundy shirt that probably cost more than Marcus spent on groceries in a month. "From small-town restaurant owner to confident performer. The wardrobe needs to tell that story along with your dancing." She stepped back to examine her work, tilting her head thoughtfully. "Roberto, what do you think about adding some subtle sparkle to his performance pieces? Nothing too flashy, but something that catches the light when he moves."

Roberto nodded enthusiastically, already pulling sequined fabric samples from a nearby drawer. "Yes, but we keep it masculine, sophisticated. He's not a Vegas showgirl, he's an artist expressing himself through movement." They continued their discussion as if Marcus were a mannequin, and he found himself wondering how many other people had stood in this same spot, being transformed from ordinary individuals into television personalities.

The interview session that followed was held in a small studio filled with professional lighting equipment and cameras that looked intimidatingly expensive. Marcus sat in a chair that was positioned to catch the afternoon light streaming through carefully positioned windows, while a makeup artist touched up his face and a sound technician clipped a small microphone to his shirt. The producer conducting the interview, a woman named Jennifer with kind eyes and a warm smile, explained that these segments would be used throughout the season to provide context and backstory for the viewers.

"Let's start with something easy," Jennifer said, settling into her chair across from him. "Tell me about your restaurant. What made you decide to leave Seattle and open Rosemary's in Cheney?" Her voice was conversational, but Marcus could see the camera operators adjusting their equipment, and he felt suddenly self-conscious about every word, every gesture, every expression that might be broadcast to millions of people.

He talked about the divorce, though in carefully neutral terms, explaining how he'd wanted a fresh start somewhere nobody knew his story. He described the challenges of running a small restaurant, the satisfaction of creating dishes that brought joy to people's lives, the way cooking had always been his form of artistic expression. Jennifer nodded encouragingly, asking follow-up questions that drew out more details, and gradually Marcus began to relax into the conversation.

"Now, I have to ask about David," Jennifer said gently, and Marcus felt his shoulders tense despite his best efforts to remain calm. "You two were married for five years. What was that relationship like, and how do you feel about potentially working with him again on this show?" The question hung in the air between them, and Marcus could feel the weight of the cameras capturing his reaction, the way his jaw tightened slightly and his hands gripped the arms of his chair.

Marcus took a deep breath, choosing his words carefully. "David and I had a good relationship for a long time. We supported each other's careers, we traveled together, we built a life that worked for both of us. But eventually, we grew in different directions, wanted different things. The divorce was difficult, but it was the right decision for both of us." He paused, looking directly into the camera for the first time. "As for working with him on the show, I think we're both professional enough to focus on the dancing and the competition. Whatever personal history we have, we left that behind two years ago."

Even as he said the words, Marcus wasn't sure he believed them. The truth was more complicated, messier, full of the kind of emotional landmines that made for compelling television but terrible life experiences. David hadn't just been his husband; he'd been his best friend, his confidant, the person he'd imagined growing old with. The end of their marriage had felt like losing half of himself, and he'd spent the past two years learning how to be whole again as a single person. The idea of seeing David again, of potentially having to touch him, dance with him, pretend that they were just two people who happened to share a past, felt both terrifying and oddly thrilling.

**Chapter 2: Reunions and Revelations**

The morning sun was barely creeping over the Los Angeles skyline when Marcus arrived at the rehearsal studio, his stomach churning with a mixture of anticipation and dread that had kept him awake most of the night. The building was a converted warehouse in the arts district, its industrial exterior giving way to polished wood floors and floor-to-ceiling mirrors that reflected the early morning light in dizzying patterns. He'd arrived thirty minutes early, hoping to have some time to acclimate to the space before facing the other contestants, but as he pushed through the heavy glass doors, he realized he wasn't the only one who'd had that idea.

David stood at the center of the main studio, moving through what looked like a warm-up routine, his body flowing from one position to another with the kind of natural grace that had always made Marcus feel clumsy by comparison. He was wearing fitted black dance pants and a gray tank top that showed off the lean muscle definition he'd maintained since their college days, when he'd played tennis and run marathons while Marcus had been more interested in exploring the local food scene. His dark hair was shorter than Marcus remembered, cut in a style that emphasized the sharp angles of his jaw and cheekbones, and when he turned to grab his water bottle, Marcus caught sight of the small scar above his left eyebrow that he'd gotten falling off his bike when they were twenty-six and still thought they'd be together forever.

For a moment, Marcus considered backing out of the studio and finding somewhere else to warm up, maybe coming back when there were more people around to serve as a buffer between them. But something in David's posture, the way he was holding his shoulders just a little too high, suggested that he was just as nervous about this reunion as Marcus was. Two years was a long time to go without speaking to someone who had once been the most important person in your life, long enough for all the sharp edges of anger and hurt to wear smooth, leaving behind something more complicated and harder to define.

David must have seen his reflection in the mirror because he turned around, and for a heartbeat they just looked at each other across the empty studio. Marcus felt the familiar jolt of recognition that came from seeing someone whose face had once been as familiar as his own, noting the subtle changes that time and distance had wrought. There were new lines around David's eyes, and he'd lost some of the softness that had been there during their marriage, when stress and late nights had made both of them a little rounder around the edges. He looked good, Marcus realized with an uncomfortable twist in his chest, like someone who had found his footing after a difficult period and was moving forward with purpose and confidence.

"Hello, Marcus," David said, his voice carrying easily across the space between them. It was the same voice that had whispered good morning in Marcus's ear for five years, that had argued with him about everything from dinner plans to major life decisions, that had said "I think we both know this isn't working" on that terrible rainy afternoon that had effectively ended their marriage. Hearing it now, in this strange context, made Marcus feel like he'd stepped backward in time, even as everything else about their situation was completely surreal.

Marcus set his bag down by the wall and walked closer, trying to project a casualness he didn't feel. "David. You look..." He paused, unsure how to finish that sentence in a way that wouldn't reveal too much about the complicated knot of emotions currently residing in his chest. "You look well. I didn't know you were still dancing." It was a safe observation, neutral territory that acknowledged their shared past without venturing into more dangerous conversational waters.

"I started taking classes again after we..." David made a vague gesture that encompassed their divorce, their separation, the entire messy end of their relationship. "It helped with the stress, gave me something physical to focus on. I never imagined it would lead to something like this, though." He gestured around the studio, and Marcus could see the same mix of excitement and terror in his ex-husband's eyes that he'd been feeling since getting on the plane in Spokane.

They stood there for a moment in awkward silence, and Marcus found himself cataloging the familiar details of David's face, the way his left eyebrow had always been slightly higher than his right, the small freckle just below his bottom lip that Marcus had kissed countless times during their years together. It was disorienting to be this close to someone who had once shared his bed, his dreams, his daily routines, and now felt like a stranger wearing a familiar face. The intimacy they'd once shared seemed like something that had happened to different people, a story he'd heard secondhand rather than lived through himself.

"How's the restaurant?" David asked, and Marcus could hear genuine interest in his voice despite everything that had passed between them. During their marriage, David had been supportive of Marcus's culinary ambitions, had encouraged him to take risks and pursue opportunities that Marcus had been too afraid to attempt. It had been one of the sources of tension between them toward the end, David's frustration with what he saw as Marcus's unwillingness to dream bigger, to step outside his comfort zone and really reach for the success he was capable of achieving.

"It's good. Small, but we're building a following. The food scene in Cheney isn't exactly Seattle, but there's something to be said for being the only game in town." Marcus realized he was downplaying his success, falling back into old patterns of self-deprecation that had driven David crazy during their marriage. Rosemary's was actually doing better than just good – they'd been featured in several regional magazines, and food bloggers were starting to make the drive from Spokane specifically to try his menu. But talking about his achievements with David felt dangerous somehow, like claiming too much success might invite criticism or comparison.

David's smile was complicated, mixing what looked like genuine pride with something that might have been regret. "I'm glad you took the leap. I always knew you had it in you to run your own place." The words hung between them, loaded with the history of their arguments about Marcus's career, his tendency to choose security over opportunity, the way he'd turned down jobs in better restaurants because they would have meant longer hours or more pressure or the possibility of failure on a larger stage.

Before Marcus could formulate a response that wouldn't lead them into the minefield of their shared past, the studio doors opened and other contestants began filtering in. Marcus felt a mixture of relief and disappointment as their private moment was interrupted, the space filling with the chatter and energy of people preparing for what they all knew would be a challenging day. He recognized a few faces from the brief glimpses he'd caught at the airport and hotel – there was a young woman with bright red hair who moved like a trained dancer, an older man who looked like he might be a ballroom specialist, and several others whose backgrounds and stories Marcus could only guess at.

The arrival of the other contestants shifted the dynamic in the room, transforming it from an intimate space where two ex-husbands were carefully navigating their first conversation in two years into a professional environment where everyone was sizing up the competition. Marcus found himself grateful for the distraction, using the opportunity to put some physical distance between himself and David while still maintaining the pretense that their reunion was no big deal, just two mature adults who happened to share some history.

Ashley, the production assistant who had picked him up at the airport, appeared with her ever-present clipboard and that bright smile that seemed to be permanently fixed to her face. She was followed by several camera operators and sound technicians, and Marcus realized that their morning warm-up was going to be filmed, their interactions and reactions captured for potential use in future episodes. The presence of the cameras changed everything, adding a layer of performance to even the most mundane interactions, and he saw several contestants unconsciously straightening their posture and arranging their faces into more television-appropriate expressions.

"Good morning, everyone!" Ashley's voice carried easily through the studio, cutting through the various conversations and drawing everyone's attention to where she stood near the mirrors. "Welcome to day one of rehearsals for America's Greatest Dance Challenge. We're going to start this morning with individual assessments, where our choreographers will work with each of you to get a sense of your current skill level and discuss the pieces you'll be performing for tomorrow night's premiere episode."
